DOC.HEAD: Seven Die in Texas Crash
DOC.TEXT: Two cars collided on a West Texas highway Sunday, killing seven people, police said. The crash occurred on U.S. Highway 67 about 27 miles south of Marfa when a vehicle carrying one man crossed the center line and struck the other vehicle, which was carrying six people, said Department of Public Safety Trooper Mark Riordan. The identities of four of the victims were withheld until relatives could be notified. The others, all occupants of the second car, were identified as Richard L. Armendariez, 29, Noe Armendariez Molinar, 27, and Vanessa Armendariez, 8. All were from Rankin, but their relationship was not immediately known, police said. ``I would have to say this is probably the worst collision since the bus crash,'' Riordan said, referring to the September school bus crash in Alton, Texas, that killed 21 students. In Flagstaff, Ariz., fog and ice were blamed for Saturday's 62-vehicle chain pileup that killed six people, injured 34 and kept sections of Interstate 40 closed for 17 hours. Twenty-four people remained hospitalized Sunday, four in critical condition, authorities said.
